ACT
192
Death certificate Drawing up a death certificate
When a person dies or is declared dead, the registrar responsible for entering the fact of death in the death register will draw up a death certificate and submit it to the court, or hand it over to the person at whose request he drew it up.
The death certificate is drawn up on the basis of data from the death register, data obtained from relatives of the deceased, from persons with whom the deceased lived and from other persons who can provide them.
If an incomplete death certificate or only an extract from the register of the deceased is submitted to the probate court, it will determine all the information that the death certificate should contain on the minutes of the probate hearing.
The death certificate has the probative force of a public document only with regard to data taken from the death register.
